Longo was trained in revolutionary techniques and tactics in Moscow.
He is a veteran of fighting with the international brigades in the Spanish
civil war and the northern Italian underground in World War II. If the Commu-
nists ever should take over Italy, many observers believe the combination of
strong man Longo and senator Pietro Seochia of the Cominfoma might reduo*
Togllattl to figurehead status or shove him out of the picture altogether.
But even the humor-less, gray-haired, 54-year-old Longo does not fit the
Communist revolutionary stereotype in appearance, andhe usually remains silent
in the Chamber, apparently preferring to do his rabble-rousing at party rallies.
The man who does look like American newspaper cartoonists think a Commun¬
ist revolutionary should look is Giuseppe di Vittorio, the secretary general
of Italyfs biggest labor union, the Co/emunist-dominated CGIL. Di Vittorio has
a broad,-powerful torso fitted onto short legal a large, squarish head, with a
heavily-lined, dark-complexioned face and a thick shook of black hair. He
generally sits in the second row from the well of the Chamber.
My characterization of him as the stereotype of the Communist revolution¬
ary in appearance may be unfair. Italian friends of mine who are strongly
anti-Gommunist say Di Vittorio is, by all odds, the most typically Italian of
any of the Communist loaders. Ttiey think he might be the one most apt to balk
at following the undiluted Moscow line if the Communists actually gained power
in Italy.

ilgnorlna Diaz was the real glamor girl of Italian Communist ranks when
she first came to aontecltorlo. At 34 she is still a slim, attractive brunet,
who generally sits near DI Vittorio in the second row of the first section.
Incidentally, Blgnorina Diaz is one of 33 women deputies in a Chamber of
590 members. Qf those 33, the Communists have 16j the governing Christian
Democratic party has 11; the left-wing Socialists four and the Monarchists two.
Well, I have gone into such detail about the Communist deputies Q&fc to
glamorize them in any way nor to make them seem more formidable than they
actually are.
But Americans impatient with the Italian government for not taking strong
enough measures against communis® need to be reminded that the problem looks
different at this end. It is one thing to cope with the Communists in a country
such as our own, where they have never been able to poll 100,000 votes, and
where the problem la one of espionage and sabotage. It is quite a different
thing to cope with the Communists in a country where they and their allies
command the allegiance of better than one out of three voters.
Those 143 Communist deputies and 75 fellow-traveling Socialists canH
simply be wished out of existence. Neither can they be legally thrown out of
the Chamber, so long as they play the parliamentary game according to the rules,
which they generally do.
